titleStmt.title: Minutes of the TEI Technical Council
titleStmt.meeting: TEI Technical Council FTF meeting : Cologne 24–26 February 2018

sourceDesc.p: Retagged from a Google Doc draft

body.p:
TEI Technical Council
Spring F2F Agenda, 2018-02-24/26 10:00 (local)
Sat 02-24 / Sun 02-25 Thomas-Institut , Universität zu Köln, Universitätsstraße 22
Mon 02-26 Neues Seminargebäude, Room S23 , Universität zu Köln, Universitätsstraße

list.item: Syd Bauman (SB)
Elisa Beshero-Bondar (EB)
Hugh Cayless (HC)
James Cummings (JC)
Elli Mylonas (EM)
Martina Scholger (MS) (Chair)
Peter Stadler (PS)
Sarah Stanley (SS)
Magdalena Turska (MT)
Raffaele Viglianti (RV)
Alejandro Bia (AB) (via Google Hangouts)

Release report (HC & MS)
Problems with permissions on website.
New CMS?
Council needs to have access to update our minutes (and other parts that need to be changed during releases)—we need this now. MS will push for completion on new website platform (preview at ).
Action on MS to address the Board — due 2018-03-10.
Release documentation has been updated for clarity.
Slack worked well.
oXygen plugin release has problems. HC has patched?
More frequent releases (JC) if we have something new. But in that case, could do the Guidelines, not Stylesheets because oXygen plugin likely has to be remade each time for Stylesheets.

Rub-a-dub report
SB: No progress since phone teleconference

Ticket assignment report
SB: We should be putting ticket assignment information in a logical place + some mechanism for reminding people.

Periodicals SIG
Abstract:
Publications with any kind of regular publication cycle, from several times a day to cycles of several years, arguably form the majority of (printed) texts nowadays. They span from newspapers via almanacs to comics and many others.
While these different types all have their own needs, their periodicity means that there are special questions to keep in mind when systematically encoding them.
The SIG Periodicals and Newspapers will focus on aspects that are common to all these kinds of periodicals:
How to encode this periodicity with its aspects in a concise and machine readable way;
How to deal with parts of periodicals that have their own periodicity (e.g. weekly, monthly etc. additions); AB: I see it more as a matter of date-stamping than periodicity.
How to deal with texts continued over several issues of a periodical;
How to encode the title of e.g. a newspaper (which usually do not cover an entire page).
Additionally, the SIG will focus on methods and workflows for preparing full texts of periodicals by means of OCR and related technologies.
MS responds to SIG in the affirmative, and suggests including some of the points above in order to make the SIG more attractive to a broader audience.
Suggestions from Council to include in SIG description: questions re encoding of advertising, page layouts, and negative space.
SS to send notes to MS with suggestions for expansion (based on Victoria meeting ).
MS ask Luis Meneses for Wiki and mail address.

Fall F2F in Tokyo
Conference is 09-09 – 09-13: .
MT wants to have workshops, and for Council meeting not to coincide with workshops.
Ask local organizers if before or after is better.
Our meeting cannot overlap with Board meeting (as both HC & MS attend Board).
TEI2018 Program committee volunteers: RV, PS, MT, SS, AB, EB.

Set up a shared calendar, shared Google Docs, minutes
Action on HC to set up calendar using TEIConstorium at gmail.com account by 2018-03-10.

Open TEI Council meeting
2018-02-26, 10:00–12:00, 7 guests
Introduce GitHub, issues, and the work of the Technical Council.

TEI offices history
History of demographics of TEI contributors, MT asks the treasurer (HC) for help gathering the relevant data.

TEI Web Services and Infrastructure
Jenkins generally
Continuous integration—which services are problematic?
PS: Releases help to demonstrate all the intersecting pieces. Need PHP instance, etc.
A single global infrastructure would help in a Docker image—to be run at Paderborn, Oxford, etc. All the requirements in place in Docker.
Currently we’re creating Jenkins artifacts, but not the entire web service. Ideally, we are publishing Docker images (from Dockerhub). tei-c.org should eventually point to one machine.
Entire TEI website, or just the Guidelines and Tools?
We need better documentation of the various pieces (including eXist integration).
RV: Maybe we can exclude the Roma part, because Roma JS is coming—just to make this easier. Instead of trying to figure out dependencies of old Roma.
MT: maybe a sub-group should make a Martina Scholger2019-07-09T21:19:06what is TR?TR of all this—architecture diagram.
sub-group PS, HC, MT, JC.
reviewers: EB, SB, Martin Holmes, others?
Jenkins on Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC)—Jenkins report (EB): needs to use singularity wrapper. Issues with supercomputing nodes communicating with the outside world—need documentation on this (PS working on it.)
PS: How to boost efficiency in the Jenkins build process? We should be refactoring the build process and implementing parallelization.
Travis CI—HC’s understanding is that our build process is too expensive for it to run, so perhaps we should set up a lightweight test suite—but can set up for any GitHub site.
Docker Images
Fragility of having single individuals supporting this (will they continue after they leave Council); need cloud hosted solutions not reliance on Paderborn, UVic, etc. (Oxford is a case we should learn from.)
HC: We can only rely on individuals. But perhaps PS’s work will make things easier to transfer. EM and EB: Documentation will help! SB: Should we be hiring someone to do this? MT (and others): We need a clear vision of how everything works. PS: OS interdependencies need to be documented.
JC: “Meta-fragility” Someone needs to understand Docker (or Singularity). HC: Again, this is the point of the documentation. JC agrees and encourages the documentation to be explicit and not focussed just on a particular solution.
MT: People can run tests on their own machines.
Website—as connected to services
OxGarage! Much of our stuff relies on OxGarage behind the scenes but we don’t really support it well.
Validation problems: Issue created to address it
Roma
Debian Packages: SB loves them. PS: This is one of the services we provide. We need a Docker image for this to be run universally. JC: A release would involve updating these Docker images.
The signature (including passphrase) will have to be passed into the Docker image somehow.
Github
eXist-db that Roma and OxGarage relies on?
Jenkins build consolidation: SB reporting from Martin Holmes:
Documentation build (builds the TEI Guidelines in English first).
Build epubs/PDF.
Then build in the 9 other languages.
HC: Where in the build flow is it most efficient to parallelize these tests? Some tests depend on output of previous tests—some linearity is necessary. Need to study the whole process to see where it can branch. Test in Japanese instead of English, maybe?
Martin’s proposal: Combine the three jobs: TEIP5-test, with TEIP5-Documentation, and TEIP5. They’re currently chained in order—he says we make them one job on one of the servers, then test it for speed against 3-job version. He thinks this will save disk space re Jenkins processes. These are all changes to the Jenkins processes.
Discussion: This makes sense because it knocks out a lot of repetition. A successful build should run a lot faster.
Question for Martin Holmes: Yes—we think this is a good idea, and Martin should do the comparison on the same machine. Refactoring the build process needs to be studied as well.
Tickets

Saturday Afternoon (15:15 - )
Former Council chair Hugh Cayless receives a thank you present from the other Council members for his service.
Tickets

RomaJS
Quick report
A couple of UI questions to the group

StandOff proposal:
Here’s a handy HTML preview from GitHub:
Example of old standoff proposal:
We’re not agreeing on the uses of teiHeader and macro structure. We do agree that standoff section, listAnnotations and individual annotation levels require their specific metadata but not necessarily as teiHeader. MT would like to see some examples of metadata that makes sense for standoff and is concerned that allowing fully-fledged teiHeader may result in very weird constructs.
Consensus on needing to study up on open annotation to apply to multiple cases—broader applicability than we’re seeing in the proposal. Need to make sure we’re correctly implementing Open Annotation model.
Action items:
MT will prepare a short presentation on Web Annotation and also results of it’s integration attempts with TEI from the earlyPrint project.
Identify general domains for standoff use as well as more detailed use case scenarios for standoff
Different perspectives on the same material (e.g. linguistic, textual variants, transcriptional features, commentary, translations... e.g. Digital Mishnah project .
Crowdsourced corrections and annotations for large scale corpora e..g Shakespeare His Contemporaries aka earlyPrint .
As solution for overlapping hierarchies problem / separation for different encoding layers (e.g. to separate very verbose linguistic encoding.

oXygen plug-in
Nneeds a patch since oXygen release 19—required for Stylesheets releases.
Trying to figure out why this is on the agenda. There was a problem that HC fixed. It still doesn’t contain SB’s TEI customization. PS points out that it needs (non-free) an older Oxygen jar in order to compile—because the API changed, won’t build with newer versions of Oxygen and why it’s not included in the standard Jenkin’s build.
PS will look at why paths in Stylesheets aren’t working in Oxygen when they are working in OxGarage. Stylesheets group can look at it.
Action: HC/SB/MH will look at moving to new oXygen jar and report at next teleconference.
SB & EM attribute class triage report 386: free-standing attributes -> class and Duplatts spreadsheet .

Sunday Afternoon:
Susanne Haaf will be arriving at ~15:00 to join us as “invited expert”, so we should reserve this time for the LingSG tickets . Susanne could not make it in the end so we will use this time for tickets.
Blue sky thinking of TEI future?
PS and HC want to rebuild the class system. In a new system, classes would have proper inheritance.
Why did we declare class membership instead of using inheritance?
Semantic classes—we might have lots of classes with only one member.
Revamp the declaration system
What would choice look like if it weren't drawing on the model from P4?
Rebuild msDesc from objectDesc.
Embed structured msDesc elsewhere than teiHeader, in prose, say in frontmatter.
msDesc and Dictionaries—aren’t well integrated with the rest of the TEI. Why do we recommend doing things one way in Dictionaries that we could do elsewise elsewhere?
Establishing conventions for common patterns: (how do we point, etc.) to try to reduce different ways of doing the same things.
Reducing the excessive proliferation of choices for the encoder. E.g. all author elements must contain either persName or orgName, but must contain one of these. JC: This would break hundreds of thousands of documents.
Flexibility may be worth preserving, however!
P6: Requirements for moving to new P# version, e.g. P6, is described in the Birnbaum Doctrine:
“Council may break backward compatibility in a more substantial and comprehensive way (as happened with the transition from P4 to P5) with the transition to a new major TEI proposal version (e.g., P6 version 1.0.0, but not P5 99.99.0). Such transitions should only happen in response to the emergence of new technologies (e.g., the transition from SGML to XML) or the development of a new architecture that conveys substantial benefit (e.g., the development of the new class system). Historically, new major versions have emerged approximately every five years, but with P5 a new system of rolling major/minor versions has been adopted.”
Should the Guidelines have more words?
More pictures? Diagrams, to show complex concepts.
JC: Examples that are in their own ecosystem: see the wider context. Examples in the Guidelines point into whole files.
Integration with standards like IIIF; LOD; Awareness of hybrid contexts (text + images).
Make TEI be more database-friendly, and avoid redundancy, make compiled manifest versions of documents with everything necessary to understand it.
Registry of APIs and code-sharing.
AB: Get rid of overcomplexity, i.e. unnecessary complexity (referring both to the markup scheme and to the ecosystem of tools and services), e.g. too many different ways to do the same, different elements with similar semantics belonging to different tagsets. Overcomplexity makes processing and maintenance more difficult/costly. The TEI cannot be simple but can be simpler.
Tickets

Standoff-Proposal:
MT: Laurent’s proposal has too many different ways of encoding web annotation relationships, and some of it doesn’t seem consistent with the actual web annotation model.
We should draft specific requirements, as in we want a way to address an arbitrary block of text, etc.
Annotation body and annotation target need to be discreet elements, clearly mappable to the web annotation model.
RV: Do we need to replicate RDF / IIIF/ Open annotation structures in TEI? Or can we just map to them?
SB: But maybe what we have in TEI should be expressible in this structure.
RV: And linguists might want more structure. But so much work has to be done to implement this as TEI.
PS: We could point out what we don’t like in Laurent’s proposal: We want a container for annotation markup. A place to put personography kinds of things, with joins and linkGrps. Can Laurent’s proposal accommodate these things?
SB: How about note target="annotTarget" resp="whoCreated"annotation body/note
linkedDataBlock
SB and RV: We need to rewrite this a better way. Fork the repo and rewrite it instead of just pushing back against it.
We don’t like the structure, and a different way to write the annotations.
Action on: MT, HC, and SB will work on this: study the proposal closely, work on a counterproposal, have a phone call, and then respond to Laurent with a phone call.

div.head: Monday Morning (10:00–12:00)

list.item:
Seminargebäude—the little building behind the big one across the street from us now.
Open meeting for “Meet the Technical Council”
Participants:
Andreas Galffy
Sree Ganesh Thotempudi
Redmer Kronemeijer
Gerrit Brüning
Michael Dahnke
Susanne Haaf
Peter Dängeli
Thomas Kollatz
Possible issues to discuss:
1687
1679
1632
1427
Discussion with community:
Andreas Kuczera: graph model of TEI (graph SIG).
Tiziana Mancinelli: Making a task force to address accessibility issues for TEI digital projects.

Monday Afternoon:
Ticket review. Pull requests should be reviewed regularly.
Summary of upcoming conference calls:
LingSig (Action on PS)
Measurements proposal (Action on EM)
Council commends MS on an awesome Job for her first F2F as Council Chair :-)

div.p: Group B: JC, SB, SS, MS
Group C: EB, MT, EM, AB
Group C: HC, MS, EM, AB

Group A discussed getting the OxGarage validation service working with RomaJS. Upon investigation, OxGarage only supports three obsolete, hard-coded schemas (two are DTDs!). We gathered some requirements for HC to go and implement a new validation service that more-or-less completely replaces the current one. The current supported validations would be removed.

list.item: For validator, read (by default) http://www.tei-c.org/release/xml/tei/custom/schema/ and list available schemas.
Input customization name and POSTed file to be validated. No uploading schema files.

Schematron validation
question whether do Relax NG / XSD validation with Schematron in a single pass or separately.
Roma needs fragment validation.

div.p: RomaJS could be bundled as a frontend for OxGarage in the OxGarage Docker distribution.
HC will also look at rate-limiting for OxGarage, since apparently it is abused for batch conversion.

row.cell: Subgroup recommends adopting the constraints (likely as Schematron)

cell.p: Subgroup wants to add model.notelike to the content model of witness. On ticket: “sounds as if adding note inside witness is not a problem. But the question is where, does it go? macro.limitedContent contains desc, fDescr, figDesc, fsDescr, meeting, rendition, tagUsage, witness—so adding there would add it to all these other elements where it may not make sense.

Another suggestion is adding model.noteLike to the content of witness because it affects the fewest other elements. Discussion: No, we shouldn’t use noteLike because it would permit witDetail which shouldn’t go in witness. So solution is add note as an element to the content model of witness.

ref.hi: teidata.points could be more tightly constrained

cell.p: No. Subgroup think this is probably overkill. Encoders should have options like including white spaces after commas, etc. Is it possible to have a combined datatype, btw?

row.cell: Syd suggests we have PS check with Lou Burnard about ISO.

cell.p: F2F subgroup suggests a rephrase, thus:

att.lexicographic “provides a set of attributes used for specifying standard values [AND OTHER PURPOSES], and is common to all elements in the dictionary module as well as elsewhere”. Discussion: no—really these attributes are for dictionaries. That may change with #1707.

row.cell: F2F subgroup suggests moving away from using processing-focused language in the descriptions (and towards language that describes the effects). We suggest utilizing language like “is part of,” instead of “is added to”. Subgroup thinks notes/remarks look good.

cell.p: We think this has to do with ODD modes of add, replace, change, and we want some clarification on the usage of the desired attribute, and what’s wrong when processing the modes with remarks and exemplum. In Issue 272 , it looks like the problem is that we’re suppressing the output of remarks and exemplum when mode="change". @ident seems to be problematic because it’s meant to be a unique identifier. Perhaps we need @type or something like it—something categorical?
Discussion: Ticket is Go for SS to implement @mode and @ident, as it is done on valItem.

ref.hi: Review placement of classes, macros, and datatypes in modules

row.cell: Definitely needs more work. At least a subgroup of two or three people to work out all the movements.
Subgroup recommends a small working group (with a Council member on it) to move this along.
Council agrees exemplums should be members of att.identified.

ref.hi: The namespace could be mentioned more prominently in the guidelines

row.cell: Subgroup recommends Ch. 1 for introduction to namespaces and ref 23.4.4 and reference it in Ch. 22 and 23. 23.4.4 describes use of TEI namespace—maybe not as prominently as the ticket requests. Ch. 1 could introduce the TEI namespace, and link to Ch. 23.4.4. could indicate all relevant namespaces in 23, but make appendix as for elements, attributes.

cell.p: RV: mode="clone" only permitted on elements in att.identified. Greenlighted to work in feature branch. Needs a Stylesheets ticket. And RV requests it to be implemented by June so Roma JS can pick it up. But the other option is that RomaJS does not deal with it in first release. That seems better.

list.item: Subgroup has reviewed this...

ref.hi: the `affiliation` element appears somewhat abused; `bio` would be better

row.cell:
This ticket refers to abuses of the use of affiliation for contents which are not actually affiliation stuff. Suggests using bio for wide biographical data. Then discussion becomes a snowball of suggestions: bio, shortBio, biogNote, note type="bio", etc., and a list of possible contained elements.
placeName already added to affiliation #1692
Answer this ticket saying in contexts like jTEI, use note type=”bio”
Biography in personography is a new and bigger issue. If current elements are not enough they can open a new ticket.

cell.p: This ticket is go (from Open Council meeting). From the ticket:
New suggested subclass includes: kinesic, move, pause, q, said, sp, spGrp, stage, u, vocal, writing
This would exclude annotationBlock, change, incident, setting, shift. We can call it att.directed.

ref.hi: Things we'd like to do in ODD which haven't been implemented yet
q should be allowed in span

row.cell: Subgroup thinks the choice is use mentioned or soCalled or we add q to the content model of span. We don’t want to add the whole qLike class.

ref.hi: seal element description should be expanded to other authentication mechanisms

row.cell: Subgroup thinks James should do the proposed rewording. If Georg Vogeler wants to propose an authentication section — he should submit a proposal.

ref.hi: model.physDescPart is declared in the wrong module

row.cell: Subgroup thinks the way to do this is with msPart or msFrag; we suggest to close the ticket and reopen it when Torsten Schaßan is coming up with a good and convincing example.

ref.hi: description of classDecl needs revision, perhaps examples

row.cell: Go! Patch in those examples, please.

ref.hi: egXML needs a way to highlight renditional aspects in the example

row.cell: This should not be discussed on Monday. We’ll sacrifice one of our other tickets instead. JC should remove the commented out prose completely. Rest of ticket about @rend in egXML should be revisited if someone wants it. JC: I do want it! (for encoding existing egXMLs). And it would potentially be very useful for the Guidelines. How should one highlight just the closing tag of a single element in an egXML? Or one element, or the ‘changed’ element between two examples, etc.

ref.hi: Status of Schematron rules in TEI

row.cell: EB will make a proposal outside of the dev branch.
JC is right. Wait for Laurent or others to comment before closing.

ref.hi: xsl:* (or other non-sch:*) not allowed within constraintSpec

row.cell: How far did go to resolve the issue of processing XSL within Schematron and SQF in ODDs? Looks like this changed the @scheme from isoschematron to schematron....(anything more?) Council resolves to test a simple change (as now indicated on ticket).

ref.hi: Pure-ODD content model elements appear to be strictly weaker than regular languages -- intended?

row.cell: Complete test suite for empty in stylesheets also, deprecate content.
Has anyone scheduled that follow-up meeting with Michael Sperberg-McQueen and Lou Burnard?

ref.hi: `path` should exist alongside `zone` for non-closed areas in facsimile
clarify how to encode short-form citations

cell.p: Where are the examples called for in the ticket? Really, what we need now are examples.
Google Doc with a collection of examples for this ticket = Discussion from teleconference ( March 2017 ).

row.cell: Pull request (for Ling Sig, so postponing until upcoming conference call).
